document.text: With the largest western armies ever to m eet on a field of battle up to that tim e, Bull Run, in the summer of 1861 in the U .S. Civil War, was one of the worlds memorable battles. M aneuvering began in June. The battle was fought July 21st. On the southern side the commanding general, in the beginning, was a Louisianian, General Pierre Beauregard, who had been named superintendent at W est Point by President Lincoln, who then rescinded the appointment. General J.E. Johnston of Virginia took command soon after the battle opened, but follow ed Beauregards plan of action. General Irvin McDowell of the Union Army was confident his well equipped force would rout the rebels and advanced boldly on Bull Run Creek and the town of M anassas, Virginia. He flung fifteen thousand good soldiers and much artillery against the Confederate left flank that day, and only the arrival of reinforcem ents, including the Stonew all Jackson brigade and Wade Hamptons legion, saved the day for the Confederates.

document.text: WASHINGTON.As tension in the Pacific continues to grow, the navy states that outstanding progress on the construction of Pacific island and Alaskan bases and shore es tablishments designed to service the navys sea and air forces has been reported by its bureau of yards and docks. In short, the navy said, the new Pacific bases program is keep ing well apace of the general ex pansion program of the navy in building up the nations two-ocean navy to the greatest array of sea power the world has ever seen. Asserting that the base construc tion program is in many places far ahead of progress originally hoped for in their construction, the statement added that the program for construction of an air base on Midway island was completed far ahead of schedule and that con siderable expansion is under way. About 24,000,000 was involved in this single project, the statement said. The statement continued Show Real Speed. Exceptional speed was made in the development of Alaskan air bases at Sitka, Kodiak and Dutch Harbor. v The original program at Kodiak is substantially completed, although original surveys were not made un til September, 1939, and construc tion started early in 1940. The size of this base has been greatly increased and additional construction providing for enlarge ments over the initial program is proceeding satisfactorily regardless of rigorous winter conditions of the location. The additional construc tion has been planned so as not to interfere with the use of sections of the base already completed. Shows Progress. Development of the air base at Sitka is even further along than at Kodiak. Likewise, progress has been satisfactory at Unalaska. Nec essary barracks and recreational facilities for personnel have been erected and occupied. Extensive recreational facilities have been provided for men stationed in these points where the normal diversions of continental posts are lacking. Another project on which out standing progress has been made is the great drydock at Pearl Har bor. The dock is in the dry and basically complete. The great dock will take any of the navys battle ships or aircraft carriers. The Kaneohe air base on the island of Oahu is in operation and enlargements are now being car ried forward. Satisfactory progress is being made at Palmyra and Johnston islands, Redwood Enduring Wood of the coast redwood tree is remarkably enduring, being very resistant to insect attack and fire.

document.text: Washington, D. a The conven ience ot the modem match tends to conceal the mUlenlums of primitive mans struggle to make Are. How difficult and Important an achieve ment this control was Is brought out by Dr. Walter Houghs study of the fire-making apparatus In the Natlon- al Mnseum, published by the Smith- sonian Institution. This Is a revision and modernization of a work first  published 40 years ago and which has long been unavailable to collector The origin of fire making, writes! Doctor Hough, need not be put very far back in time. For ages before men knew bow to make It, he contin ues, they preserved fire after lighte ning and volcano had brought It on. Illustrating the extraordinary ability developed by primitive peoples In the preservation of fire be Instances the Cherokee Indians of North Carolina who kept fire buried In the mounds, upon which the council houses were built, so that If the house were de- stroyed by enemies the fire would re- main there for a year or more. Flreless Period In History Doctor Hough questions the theory that fire Is indispensable to all hu mankind under all conditions, polnt- I Ing out that very many fire myths pos-  sessed by primitive peoples recount a stage of firelessness and a wresting of fire from those having It Doctor Hough believes that the va rious methods of producing fire by friction of wood on wood probably preceded the methods Invoking the use of minerals. He suggests a means by which man may have developed the friction method, after a long pre liminary period during which man1 gained a growing acquaintance with the properties of various substances.  . . Friction is a common experi ence and handling wood or working in wood might give to keen percep tions an odor, a vapor of smoke, sug gesting that there was fire present, . . . . which could be brought out by friction. That the primitive fire tool should take the nature of a drill is explained by the ancient character of the drill for piercing holes in all kinds of sub stances byabrasion.- In the early explorations of Amer ica, the Indian, almost without excep tion, used the friction apparatus con sisting of two sticks of wood. Primitive methods of fire mnr.g aid In determining racial relation ships. Thus about all Eskimo tribes use a four-piece fire drill, consist ing of a mouthpiece, a drill, a cord, for turning the drill, and a hearth, and other races have their own par ticular methods. The use of the mouth drill Is almost more than the white mans teeth will stand. Nature Demonstrates Way. , i In the Malay archipelago nature  seems to have shown the way to make  fire. It appears that many fires arc  started in the jungle by bamboo rub  bing together In a high windstorm  Thus the natives use two specially cut  pieces of bamboo which when sawed   one against the other produce fire. ! In view of the history of fire, its   Importance to man, its power, and   the mystery of it, there need be no 11 surprise at the existence In many ! I parts of the primitive world of fire   worship. Even In our day something 1 of this attitude toward fire can be l found among certain African tribes.   Doctor Hough quotes H. H. Johnston   to the effect that among the Wata- 1 veita fire making is the exclusive E privilege of the men, and the secret  l Is banded down from father to son.   and never under any condition re   vealed to women. A man was asked   the reason for this. Oh, said he,   If women knew how to make fire   they would become pur masters. I Among some Africans who are mas- IP ters in metal work the anomalous  l custom obtains of using wooden drills  l to light the fire which melts their I I Iron. Two pieces of pyrites or a flint and  pyrites appear to have been the first   agencies used for producing a spark L by percussion. In North America the   percussion method Is found in use   among the northerly ranging Indians   and the Eskimo of some parts. I Doctor Houghs study Is based on  the National mnseum cntlwHn 0f 1

In reply to an inquiry he said that at present be was nnable to tell tbe extent of tbe setback, but hardly anticipated a change of great seriousness, and would not make another visit to tbe patient before his regular time unless a call should come for him. A reporter endeavored to obtain an audi ence with James G. Blaine, Jr., relative to Mr. Blaines unfavorable turn, but was in formed that he was not at hoiue. A re quest for an interview with some member of tbe family was unsuccessful. The at tendant at tbe door said that all the family cared to say was that Mr. Blaine to not so well. -

document.text: W a s h in g t o n , D. C., Jan. 27. Mr. Blaine died at U oclock this morning. He passed a restless night and this morn Qg was very weak. Shortly before 0 oclock a change for the worse ocourred and both physicians were hastily autn- moned and remained at the bedside un til be died. HU death was calm and pesoefu! and he retained consciousness until a few minutes before death. HU entire family, Miss Dodge, and trained nurses were at the bedside. Dr. Hyatt said that H r. Blaines death was doe to sheer exhaustion. He was unwilling to makea statement regarding the disease of Mr. Blaine until be receiv ed the consent of the family. The news of Mr. Blaines death spread like wild-llre. Crowds gathered on the oorner and visitors flocked to the boose. Dr. Hamlin, who was pawing the boose when the announcement of death was made,at onoe entered and remained with the family for some time. Word was tnt to the President Immediately after the death. At 114 President Harrison, accompanied by Private Secretary Hal ford and Lieut. Parse, walked over to the Blaine mansion. The President showed marked signs of griei. Post master-General Waoamaker followed the footsteps of the. Prealdeut. To a reporter Dr. Johnston said I was called tbU morning to the Blaine residence about MO oclock and found him In a very exhausted condition. He baa grown weaker daring the early morning hours and about 830 oclock the nurse observed that hU breathing was more difficult and his pulse more feeble than R has been. Dr. H yatt was also sent for and arrived th-r about 10 oclock. After my arrival Mr. Blai- e cmtaued to grow weaker very rapi -ly, his pulse becoming more fer-ble. H- died a t 11 oclock. Ho was perfectly coujclou up to itbiu a fe moments of bU de tb and iveoguiz d all those around him. He died without suffer ing. Th- President had been warned of Mr Blaines approaehlng end ihm uth the pi ess bulletin wnicb iufnrmed him tuai Mr. Blaine could not live through the day. A few minutes later he receive be anuouuoemaut of his death. The Cabinet was immediately notified. Sec retary Foster, of the State Department, was at home preparing to leave town when he was notified by telephone ol Mr. Blaines death. He postponed bis trip aud ordered the Department to be dosed. The Provident issued a procla mation, announcing the death of Mr. Blaine aud directing that oo the day of the funeral all executive departments at Washington be closed that on all public buildings throughout the U utedSiatcv, the national flsg be displayed at half staffand for thirty days the Stale De partm ent be draped in mourning. At 1-J0 p. m., it was stated by friends of the family that the funeral arrange ments had been so far determined upon Set services would be held Monday forenoon and the remains would be, at least temporally, interred here In Wash ington City. Whether the funeral will be public or private, or whether the final resting place be here or at some chosen spot in Maine or elsewhere is not at this hour definitely settled. t h i cxnss or his death . In answer to a direct question. Did Blaine die of Brights disease? Dr. Johnston said While there has been during the last several months evidences of chronic of the kidneys, being a form of what is commonly known as Brights disease, yet this was not the sole cause of his death. There were other consecutive complications which tended to exhaust him and to hasten the end. Lapses which be has had from time to time were due to heart exhaustion, that is, feebleness and irregularity of the action of the heart, accompanied by difficult breath ing.Daring yesterday nothing of impor tance ooourred. Mr. Bl Ine lay there in a feeble condition, taking but very litue nourishment. Indeed, he has taken but very little nourishment since his serious attack of December 18th, and this has oonsiste 1 aim st whollv of milk. At no time has he had any difficulty with his stomafth, and he has been able to digest whatever food was given him. Tnrough ut his long illness he has been able to reoognizs members of hi family and his physicians. Wnile he ha not conversed to any extent, even with his family, for some time ptst, he has always been able to indioate bis want very clearly. To questions whioh have been asked him - he has always replied intelligently, but in monosyllables. Mr. J bnsou further said that there hid been really no hope of Mr. Blaines utiim ite reoovery slime that Sunday in December, hot up to within the last two v or three w-eks strong hope had been entertained that his life might be pro longed. Since that time, however, there has been no hope. No effort has been made to sustain life by the use of atlm- utants, and praotioally nothing has been done except to give him nourishment. document.text: vitation to attend ihertiorial ex ercises in Atlanta brought him a warm welcome. He rode with General Kirby - Smith in a flow er bedecked carriage drawn by a pair of coal black horses, with the Governors Horse Guard as an escort. As they moved to take their place in the procession, a shout went up from the crowd Thats Johnston! Thats J o e Johnston! Men who had served under him pushed forward and surrounded the carriage. Amid shouts and yells they lifted the vehicle and its occupants from the ground. Finally, some one shouted, Take the horses away! In a moment the team was out of the traces and the carriage moved forward drawn by the veterans.

document.text: Under Three Flags, a mission study book of the Womans Society of Christian Service, is being taught at Mt. Comfort every Sun day evening this month at 7 30. Last Sunday evening, Mrs. O. W. Martin, Jr. introduced the book and gave some political and geographical facts relating to the three republics, India, Pakistan and Ceylon. This Sunday, Mrs. A. M. Johnston will speak on India, and the following Sunday, Mrs. Hubbard Moore and Mrs. Alton Moore on Pakistan and Ceylon. The study will conclude with a drama, depicting the relationship of the church and life in these south-Asian countries.

document.text: uary ,3 1807. His father, Peter Johnston served in the Ameri can Revolution,  and later be came a distinguished jurist. His mother was a niece of Patrick Henry. General Johnston was graduated from West Point in the class with G e n e r a l Rob ert E. Lee. He s e r v e d in the Black Hawk and Mexican wars, and was severely wounded in -the latter. In i860 he was ap pointed quartermaster general, United States Army, with the rank of Brigadier General. On April 22, 1861, he resigned his commission, and was appointed General and assigned to the com mand of the Shenandoah Valley. He commanded a force a Harp ers Ferry and formed a junction with General. P G. T. Beaure- ! yards army at Manassas. In 1862 he commanded all the Con federate forces in Virginia, and at the battle of Fair Oaks, near Richmond, May 31, 1862, was seriously wounded. Although Jef ferson Davis was hostile to him, in November 1862 he was assign ed to-the military department of Tennessee. In April 1863, he re ported himself unable to do ac tive duty. Later in the spring of 1863, he attempted to relieve Vicksburg, but was defeated at Jackson by vpjpneral Ulysses S. Grant May 14, and retreated to Canton, Mississippi. After Gen eral Braxton Bragg was defeated! by General Grant, at Chatta nooga, November 25, 1863, Gen eral Jofonstm. yas given com mand of the forces of the South west. With an army of 55,000 men he fortified the position ofJ the Confederate Army at Dalton, Georgia. General William T. Sherman atfefcked the Confed- erate forces with superior Fed eral forces, and General Johns- stons army was driven across, the Chattahoochee. General John ston reached Atlanta in July, and was determined to hold it to the end. Authorities at Richmond were dissatisfied and on July 17, 1864, he was ordered to turn over his command to General J. B. Hood. Near the end of February 1865, after General Sherman had captured Atlanta, marched to Savannah and into South Caro lina, Johnston at Lees request, was assigned to the command1 of the army of Tennessee, and all troops in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida. His objec tive was to concentrate all available forces and drive back Sherman. He was defeated at Bentonville, N. C. After the close of the war Gen eral Johnston engaged in civic endeavors. In 1874 he published a Narrative qf Military Opera tions during the Civil War. In 1877 he was elected to represent the Richmond District in Con gress. and in 1887 he was ap pointed United States commis sioner of railroads by President

After the tour the group had a picnic supper in the recreation area of the College. The weather was nice and they enjoyed basket ball and other games. Janet Coleman gaje devotions and Sylvia Carson presided over the business meeting. Joy Johnston who has just re cently moved to Concord joined the group. Some were at Senior 4-H Camp at Holiday Lake and could not be present. They were Susan Robinson and Curt Stone, Amy Roberts and Teresa Roberts and their lamilies joined in the tour and picnic supper. document.text: Trinkle Won y 22,691 Ballot. Richmond. The official returns from the pri mary of August 2, certified by the board of canvassers, show that out of a total vote of 150,669 cast, B. Lee Trinkle, the successful candidate for the Democratic nomination tor the governorship, reoelved 86,680, while hta opponent, H. St. George Tucker, re ceived 63,989, Mr. Trinkles majority being 22,691. Mr. Trinkle carried the First, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth Seventh aud Ninth Congressional Dis tricts, the Second, Eighth and Tenth going to Mr. Tucker. Mr. Trinkle car rled sixty-six of the 100 counties in the State and fourteen of the twenty- two cities. It is interesting to note, however, that Trinkles big vote was rolled uj In the Fifth, Sixth and Ninth Con gresslonal Districts, out of which h came with a lead ot 22,689, which, sub tracted from his total majority In the State, leaves him the exceedingly close margin of two votes over Tucker. The womens vote, which is said to have been somewhat heavier than had been anticipated, Is given to Trinkle almost In Us entirety. Th post mortem ex ports are sure that the victor may thank them for his nomination. Richmond is in the column of the cities which the official canvass gives to Mr. Trinkle. This city gave him a vote of 8,513 to Mr. Tuckers 8,242 Norfolk, which early unofficial returns had given to Mr. Trinkle. went for Mr. Tucker, the vote standing Tucker, 5,738, and Trinkle, 4,333. Portsmouth remains In the Tucker column. For the lleutenant-governshlp nom ination, Senator West won over his nearest rival, Mr. Gunn, by 11,437. The candidates for second place stood In the following order West, 56,997 Gunn, 44,560 Gilpin, 30,588 Fltzhugh. 5,544. Berkley D. Adams, candidate for the State Corporation Commission nomination, as successor to hlmsell had a majority of 60,804 over E. C. Folkes, of Richmond. Mr. Adams re ceived 100,492 votes, and Mr. Folkes had 39,688. The board of canvassers, of which James M. Hayes Jr., Is secretary, con sists of Secretory of the Common wealth B. O. James. State Auditor C Lee Moore, State Treasurer Charles A. Johnston, and Attorney-General John R- Saundera, Governor W est morelSnd Davis befng an ex-offlcW member.

document.text: Tragedy In Florida T urpentine CampNe groes Reported K illed by D eputies. Brooksville, Fla., Special.Sunday night a white man named Cleland was killed at Weeks turpentine camp, about fifteen miles from here. Cleland was one of a party sent from Johnstons turpentine camp to collect money due Johnston. As the party approached Weeks camp they were fired upon from ambush and Cleland dropped dead. Tuesday morning a sheriff nnd posse went to Weeks camp and arrested three negroes. The negroes were turned over to deputies to be brought to this place. Wednesday a negro, badly shot, was brought here. He said he and the two other negoee arrested were taken Into the scrub and fired on by tbe deputies. He managed to make his es cape. but the other negroes were, be thinks, killed.

Simultaneously came theannounce ment that Charles W. Bryan, W. J.s j brother, who was in command of the i Bryan forces gt the National Conven tions at Kansas City in 1900 and at Denver four years ago, would look  after the Interests of the Nebraskan. document.text: The Women of the Church of the Old Concord Presbyterian Church met Oct. 7 with Mrs. Bessie Chilton. The 17 members decided to make a pledge month rather than set a cer tain amount of dues. Rev. A. S. Gear installed officers for the rest of this year and for the coming year. Also there was a surprise birthday party for the hostess. Mr. David W. Smith took pictures on movie film of the cake and presents she received on her 75th birthday. The next meet ing will be held Nov. 4 with Mrs. J. D. Johnston, of Spout Spring.

document.text: The wedding of Miss Verta Robert son Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Graydon Martin of Oak ville, to Mason Elbert Banton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Benjamin Banton of Tye River, took place on June 9 at 800 P. M. in the Mount Comfort Methodist Church. The double ring ceremony was perform- e dby the pastor, the Rev. L. F. Callaham, before the altar decora ted with palms, firns, baskets of white gladioli and lighted by can dles in cathedral stands. Misses Lucille Coleman, vocalist, Minnie Bohannan, violinist, and Alice Bradley and Shirley Walton, accompanists, furnished a program of nuptial music. The bride, given in marriage by her brother, Warren C. Martin, wore white organdie, designed with close- fitting bodice, buttoned down the back with small covered buttons, and made with a lace yoke, long- pointed lace sleeves ,and a full skirt with a cathedral train and scalloped hem line. She wore a French illusion veil with a tiara of beads and seed pearls. Her only piece of jewelry was a pearl and onyx necklace, an heirloom, origi nally her maternal great- grand mothers. She carried a cascade of gardenias, stephanotis, ivy and roses. Mrs. R. Clayton Martin, sister-in- law of the bride, was matron of honor, in ice blue. Other attendants were Misses Margueritte Moore, .Betty Banton, Daphine Wells and Della Banton. Gilbert Banton was his brothers best man. Groomsmen ! were Clayton Martin, brother of the bride William C. Johnston, J. Gor don Martin and G. C. Martin. Mrs. Martin, mother of the bride, wore light blue crepe, and Mrs . 1 Banton, mother of the groom, wore navy blue. Both wore pink roses. Mrs. John C. Moore, the brides ma ternal grandmother, was in black chiffon and added gardenias at the shoulder. The brides parents entertained with a reception at their home.

document.text: The story of the wealth or Weste Canada cannot be told too often ttfij truth w illbear repeatlngs. And Isl telling of lt lt Is hoped that advantage will he taken of the great opportuni ties that Western Canada offwn, bj thpae who áre today straggling, for  mere existence, by those who are oc cupying lands, high in price and high In rentals. From grain, Uve stock and dairying Iin 1916, there was a return from .the- three Prairie. Provinces of 258.000,000, or an increase of finir million dollar over 1915, and 118 miUIon dollars over 1914. A prominent Trust Company eaya Some of our contract holders have paid off their purchase money on .lauda- bought a year ago out of this years crop, and what one man can do anoth er can do. Thousands of Southern Al berta farmers harvested an average of 40 to 50 bushels of No. 1 wheat to the acre. These farmers have moTM real money to spend than any other people on the American Continent J D. Johnston of Bladsworth, Bask., left Johnson County, Kansas, seven years - ago. -When he left he had 600 tn cash, six mules, some settlers effect and an equity In some prairie land, Mr, Johnaton tells hls story In my seven years residence i la Saskatchewan, I have raised seven good crops the value of this years T crop alone being Twenty thousand dob lara. I now own Two Sections of im proved land, 17 horses and mules, 40 cattle, a large steam thresher and  full libe of farm machinery, ,  l We have made five trips to Ktaeaa, one trip to the Pacific Coast and turn. Wa have enjoyed the society of  clast of people than whom non bet ter can be found. The cUmata is healthful and Invigorating. Tbe soil 1 fertile and productive, well adapted for the production of the beat quaUty and larga yields of all cereals and vegetables, wild and tame grasses. It la an excellent stdek country. The question of taxes Is one that carries udth - It considerable weight Coming from a man like Mr. Johnston the same weight should be given ths answer. He saysi .  i ,  1 il Tbe tax system especially commends Itself to me as being simple, reason-  able and ju st Ail direct taxes ara levied on the land at Its  appraised market value, exclusive of Improve ments thereon. No tax on personal property. This tendsto discourage - the holding of lands by speculators who prevent Its cultivation or Improve ment, hoping to realize profits from th e  enhanced value of their holdings due to the Industrial activities of thesbona fide settlers. It tends to encourage th settlers to rear substantial Improve ments upon their land without paying a penalty ln the form . of taxation therefor. It encourages the raising of live stock and the possession of other personal property necessary to the de velopment of the country.  ,  .. The lawa are well and economically administered. Citizens of the Domin ion vote on election of members of parliamsnt and members of the Pro vincial assembly, while on questions of local Improvements and school mat ters the franchise Is exercised by rate payers, Irrespective of citizenship. The people are enterprising, school facilities are good Taxation, Just and reasonable. Military service volun tary. Patriotic fervor unsurpassed, law and order the rale, and crime ths rare exception. It is the land of banks, schools, telephones, grain ele vators, broad, fertile acres, good cli mate, good citizenship and abounding tn opportunities for the indnstrlou man or Woman of good morals, ln short, the land of promise and fulfill ment, I know of no better anywhere, Advertisement

After a delicious supper the program was rendered by the Rotàrÿ Club. The chairman of the- evening was Mr. Cart- edge. A most amusing and lever toast was given the women by Dean McPherson, of Lynchburg College Mrs. Dot Woodson responded. This was ollowed by speech by Mar? py Hancock,. a- formerAppo- mattox man- It was a message af welcome to their guests and history of what  Rotary means. To this J. A. Burke responded with asplendid ad dress. Kit Caskie, of Lynch burg, thep gave more informa- tion regarding the Rotary Club The last thing pn the program add this was Most, fitting was a tribute to Lee by Mra. im. Scott. Throughout the evening the Twilight Singers, üegro .quartet rendered spirit uals . and folk .songs that charmed their audience. .   1 Senator Ferguson presented one of the..beautiful govels made of walnut from surren der grounds! trees. J. H. Johnston, of Michigan, ren- dered several selections on his banjo.., The decorations were gas kets of cut flowers, which dot- .ted.the lawn of S, A Ferguaoa where the banquet was held.? There were many distingu ished business men of the Hill City present , and all had a pleasant evening and the hope is that these gentlemen and la dies will visit us again. document.text: The P.-T. A. held its first meet ing Tuesday night at the school, with a fairly good attendance. Ev ery one was grateful to the Api.o- inattox Garment Company for its gift of 250.00 to the school to go for a dental clinic. The Junior Class elected officers Monday. They are as follows President, Billy Johnston Vice-pres., Shirley Walton Secretary, David Wood Treasurer, Sylvia Burks Reporter, Lewis Garrett Historian, Ann Goad. We are glad to see each class getting an early start and hope each one will have a successful year. I guess thats about all this week. If anyone has some news of A. IT. S. which I have overlooked, I will appreciate your telling me.

document.text: The old home of President John Ty ler, in Gloucester county, known as the Gloucester House, has been destroyed by fire. The Imperial Tobacco Company, of England, has leased a factory in Dan ville and will at once open up business in that city. Miss Mary Johnston, the authoress, paid16,500 for a lot on Franklin street, Richmond, on which she will erect a handsome residence.
